_prev_prog_3.Description: Monson Fruit Company complies with the prevention program level 3 requirements found in the WISHA PSM standard contained in WAC 296-67.  This program is organized into the following elements: 1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program wherever possible; 2) Training is provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and is periodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to restart of the system after modifications to ensure that impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's emergency plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state, and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

Prevention Program Description:



Monson Fruit Company complies with the prevention program level 3 requirements found in the WISHA PSM standard contained in WAC 296-67.  This program is organized into the following elements: 1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program where ever possible; 2) Training is provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and is periodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to restart of the system after modifications to ensure that impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident Investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's emergency plan and that notification are made to designated points of contact at local state, and federal levels depending on the extend of the release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Monson Fruit Company

Selah, WA 98942

 



RMP Executive Summary below:

 

Monson Fruit Company (hereinafter called "Monson") has two large (over 10,000#) and one small ammonia refrigeration system to quickly chill, pack and store under controlled atmosphere a variety of fruit products. The systems have a computerized process control system that monitors system performance and controls its operation.



Anhydrous Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in this system.  Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent odor that is an irritant to the eyes, nose and throat. It is normally shipped as a liquefied compressed gas and is present in portions of the refrigeration system as a liquid under pressure. Please refer to onsite data for ammonia quantities.



In order to protect its employees, the public, and the environment, the Monson facility has an integrated process safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur.  The program is designed to comply with WISHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) found in WAC 296-67 and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations found in 40 CFR Part 68. 



The Monson plant has an emergency action plan that addresses the response procedures necessary for a release of anhydrous ammonia from a refrigeration system.  Because of the pungent odor of ammonia, any leak is easily detected.  The compressor rooms are provided with ammonia detectors that sound an alarm if ammonia is detected.  The refrigeration systems are designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves.  In case of a release that could travel off the plant property, calls would be made to the Selah police and fire departments and to the Yakima County emergency services to assist in the response. 



During the last five years, there have been no reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia. Should there be an accidental release when no one was on the premises, it would be

detected by a computer control system.  Ammonia leak detectors are installed and the computer checks all areas where ammonia could possibly be.  When the computer detects ammonia it turns on the alarm and dials emergency numbers for appropriate refrigeration personnel. 



Monson makes daily inspections of the ammonia refrigeration systems to determine if there are any potential problems; in addition, a preventive maintenance program is in place and inspections, tests and maintenance are completed by qualified site and contractor ammonia refrigeration technicians.



As a result of the revision of the Process Safety Management Plans for Refrigeration Systems 1, 2, & 3 and the Risk Management Plan for Refrigeration Systems 1 & 3,all aspects of the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration systems have been reviewed and approved by the PSM Committee.
